cards.front: What is the Ebers-Moll equation for a diode?
cards.back: I_D = I_S(e^(V_D/V_T) − 1). I_S ≈ 10⁻¹⁴ A (saturation current), V_T ≈ 25 mV (thermal voltage at 300K). Exponential in forward bias, flat at −I_S in reverse.

cards.front: What is the thermal voltage V_T?
cards.back: V_T = kT/q ≈ 25-26 mV at room temperature. k = Boltzmann's constant, T = absolute temperature, q = electron charge. Appears in the exponent of the diode equation.

cards.front: What is dynamic resistance r_d of a diode?
cards.back: r_d = V_T / I_D (approximate). It is the small-signal resistance — the slope of the V-I curve at a specific operating point. At I_D = 1mA, r_d ≈ 25Ω. At 10mA, r_d ≈ 2.5Ω.

cards.front: Why does a silicon diode appear to 'turn on' at 0.6-0.7V?
cards.back: The exponential e^(V/25mV) produces negligible current below ~0.5V and milliamp-level current around 0.6-0.7V. The transition looks sudden because the exponential grows so rapidly.
Any two-terminal element is fully characterised by its V-I relationship at the terminals, regardless of internal construction. You don't need to know the physics inside — just the V-I curve.
An element whose V-I relationship is NOT of the form V = kI (constant k). Equivalently, its resistance changes with operating point. Examples: diode (exponential), MOSFET (quadratic).

cards.front: What are the three methods for solving circuits with nonlinear elements?
cards.back: 1. Graphical (load-line): plot V-I curves, find intersection. 2. Piecewise-linear (PWL): approximate curve with line segments. 3. Numerical (Newton-Raphson): computer iteration (SPICE).
Plot the nonlinear element's V-I curve and the circuit's linear constraint (load line: I = (V_supply − V)/R_load) on the same axes. Their intersection is the operating point Q.

cards.front: What is the reverse saturation current I_S?
cards.back: I_S ≈ 10⁻¹⁴ A for silicon at room temperature. It is the tiny reverse current that flows when the diode is reverse-biased. It doubles approximately every 10°C.

cards.front: Can a nonlinear circuit have multiple operating points?
cards.back: Yes! If the V-I curve intersects the load line at multiple points, there are multiple valid operating points. This is how bistable circuits (flip-flops, latches) work — two stable states.
